I'm not sure I agree. I think these disagreements have always been there, the confrontation just hasn't. Interesting take nevertheless.

@Xan: Yes and no. People weren't as busy as most people think, the amount of work to be done was really different depending on the seasons, which meant there was a lot more time in winter. Doing all of the governing in winter is probably not the best of ideas. Certainly not once your enemies realize and do all of the attacking business in summer. It's part of the reason why scandinavian houses were intricately decorated inside.

I'm not sure the NSFW icon is the appropriate one, I feel like it should be something more along the lines of "18+" or "NSFW", maybe a red exclamation mark. The icon you've used gives the impression of the content being dangerous or illegal. On top of that I think a DNS isn't the right place to be categorizing zites based on their content, although I understand it's purely visual and won't affect the resolution of marked addresses.
@Git Center: I meant installation, maintenance, etc. things one would have to spend their own time on, rather than computing resources.

@Git Center: I understand. But I'd argue that dangerous and adult are two different things and grouping them together does a disservice to the site owners of adult sites. e.g. Twitter would be "dangerous" because it contains adult content.

I treat ZeroMe like people tend to use Twitter: for everyone to see. Private communication is through ZeroMail or RetroShare. If I post something here it's because I want the world to (be able to) see it. I don't use traditional social media anymore, but I'm sure they can figure out my identity anyway, I'm not really trying to make it hard.
check out protondb as well, it's like winehq but for valve's fork of wine that's shipped with steam these days.
I personally think mainstream social media plays a larger role in student depression rates than responsibilities and expectations do.

It won't lead to centralization as it did with the early internet, visitors to the zite will still download and distribute it as well. This is just a convenience for the owner to not have to run a server 24/7.
Browserless ZeroNet applications!
The EU really doesn't seem to care about hiding how evil it is anymore.

There's a couple of performance issues with ZeroNet, particularly noticeable on large sites like KopyKate. I'm confident switching to Rust will be an improvement, but that's just push back the inevitable (as ZeroNet keeps growing), that said I have some ideas for how we could improve performance past that point. Basically my plan is 1) try to make an implementation of ZeroNet that's as efficient as I can make it, 2) find innovative ways to decrease the amount of work ZeroNet has to do to function. It makes no sense to do 2 first IMHO, because that just means 1 will be more work to do later.

@SSDifnskdjfnsdjk: My current model has sites in one thread, peers in another, the user manager in another, and websockets handled over multiple threads (database isn't integrated yet, but should be separate threads as well, plural because ZeroNet uses multiple databases). It should be possible to adapt at a later date so that a single site or peer can be handling different actions in multiple threads at the same time. It's also supposed to be async within threads, but best to ignore that for now because I'm not optimizing for that yet.

@Git Center: You're mostly right, but I do think some desktop zeronet applications could be really useful for e.g. content creators. Imagine a multiuploader that uploads your video to multiple video zites, allowing you to update them all at the same time as well. I think there's room for it, but it's probably going to be in specialized areas.

There is this language called Rust, it's great at multithreading.
There is also this project called ZeruNet, which is supposed to be a cross-compatible Rust implementation of ZeroNet.

Just have patience :-)

So **PowerPoint** - a piece of (supposedly offline) presentation editing software doesn't work without an internet connection.

Meanwhile **ZeroNet** - a p2p decentralized internet layer works fine without internet connection.

That is hilarious. Of course it's kinda logical ZeroNet works offline because having access to your locally stored parts of the network is the whole point of it. But still.
This is also why I never use cloud services like Google Docs. That, and Google being spyware.

It's sad to hear, but not surprising.

I recommend self-hosting. If you don't want to give up anonymity you could host over Tor, there's plenty of gateways for the Tor network, so clearnet people can still access it.
